title: CEOs blame investors, banks for high hurdle rates
text:
"Our hurdle rates are driven by our cost of capital and our cost of capital has not changed significantly," he said. "Because of the drop in rates, it obviously has come in, but if you look at the investment market in terms of shareholders, the shareholders are not sitting there expecting to see lower rates of return on equity."

Woolworths chief executive Brad Banducci said Dr Lowe had raised a "fair question".

"We are sensitive to the issue and whether we have the right settings," he said, adding that Woolworths' new chief financial officer Stephen Harrison was examining the issue. "We don't know to what extent we should be adjusting them."

Horizon Minerals managing director Jon Price said debt wasn't cheap for a companies like the $53 million gold explorer. Mr Price said Horizon still faced interest rates of up to 14 per cent on loans that may be required for its $52 million purchase and refurbishment of a gold mill near West Australia's Coolgardie in the state's east.

Mr Price said they will not invest in a project unless they can make a minimum profit margin of $500 per ounce. Asked why he would not invest if he could only make $300 per ounce, he said: "There is an inherent risk in mining...it often costs more, it often takes longer and the grade can often disappoint. Factor it in at the beginning and you know you have covered should any of those eventuate."

Earlier this week, Dr Lowe said that some companies had already lowered their hurdle rates in response to the RBA's interest rate cuts, and were finding more investments.

"Changing this hard-wiring is difficult and time consuming," he said.

"We do know that some companies have lowered their hurdle rates and this is opening up more opportunities for them. It would be good to hear more such reports."

Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has repeatedly urged companies to invest in growing their business, rather than return capital to shareholders.

AGL Energy chief financial officer Damien Nicks said the utility's hurdle rates hadn't changed and stood at 12 per cent, on a post tax nominal basis.

Asked about hurdle rates for new projects such as batteries at AGL Energy's investor day in Sydney, Mr Nicks said the level was "absolutely appropriate in today's market" given the projects had asset lives of 10, 15 or 20 years.

Mr Nicks said AGL had never had a project not get up because of hurdle rates, adding that good projects typically made the grade.

Any project involving a higher level of risk requires a higher hurdle rate, he said.
description: Chief executives and chairman aren't rushing to lower hurdle rates, despite urging from RBA governor Philip Lowe.
